events.originalText: A crowd crush killed 45 people during the annual pilgrimage to the tomb of Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai in Israel.
events.subtitle: 2021 Meron crowd crush
events.headline: 45 killed in crowd crush at Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai pilgrimage in Israel

events.originalText: A Dutch man drove his car at high speed into a parade in an attempt to kill the Dutch royal family.
events.subtitle: 2009 attack on the Dutch royal family
events.headline: Dutch man attempts to kill royal family by driving into parade

events.originalText: The New Yorker published an online article and photographs detailing accounts of torture and abuse by American military personnel of Iraqi prisoners held at Abu Ghraib prison in Baghdad.
events.subtitle: The New Yorker
events.headline: New Yorker exposes torture of Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib prison

events.originalText: Faustina Kowalska, a Polish nun whose apparitions of Jesus inspired the Catholic devotion to the Divine Mercy, was canonized by Pope John Paul II.
events.subtitle: Faustina Kowalska
events.headline: Polish nun Faustina Kowalska canonized by Pope John Paul II

events.originalText: Riverdance was performed for the first time, as the interval act for the Eurovision Song Contest.
events.subtitle: Riverdance
events.headline: Riverdance debuts at Eurovision Song Contest

events.originalText: Sixteen monks and a nun of the Hindu organisation Ananda Marga were beaten to death and set on fire in Calcutta, India.
events.subtitle: Ananda Marga
events.headline: 16 monks and a nun of Ananda Marga killed in Calcutta

events.originalText: American forces completed a helicopter evacuation (aircraft and evacuees pictured) of U.S. citizens, South Vietnamese civilians and others from Saigon, just before North Vietnamese troops captured the city,  ending the Vietnam War.
events.subtitle: Operation Frequent Wind
events.headline: American forces evacuate Saigon, ending Vietnam War

events.originalText: A refusal by the Bristol Omnibus Company and the Transport and General Workers' Union to permit the employment of black bus crews led to a bus boycott in Bristol, England.
events.subtitle: Bristol Omnibus Company
events.headline: Bristol bus boycott over refusal to employ black bus crews

events.originalText: World War II: As Allied forces closed in on Berlin, Nazi leader Adolf Hitler committed suicide in the Führerbunker with Eva Braun one day after their marriage.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: Adolf Hitler commits suicide in Berlin with Eva Braun

events.originalText: Second World War: The Royal Navy submarine HMS Seraph began Operation Mincemeat to deceive Germany about the upcoming invasion of Sicily.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: HMS Seraph begins Operation Mincemeat in World War II

events.originalText: The Federal Industrial Institute for Women opened near Alderson, West Virginia, as the first federal prison for women in the United States.
events.subtitle: Federal Prison Camp, Alderson
events.headline: Federal prison for women opens in West Virginia

events.originalText: Douglas Fairbanks and Mary Pickford became the first two celebrities to make imprints of their hands and feet in cement (Pickford's pictured) at Grauman's Chinese Theatre in Hollywood, California.
events.subtitle: Douglas Fairbanks
events.headline: Fairbanks and Pickford make imprints at Grauman's Chinese Theatre

events.originalText: British physicist J. J. Thomson and his team announce the discovery of the electron.
events.subtitle: J. J. Thomson
events.headline: J. J. Thomson announces discovery of electron

events.originalText: A crowd of workers, unemployed due to the Panic of 1893, concluded the first significant popular protest march on Washington D.C.
events.subtitle: Coxey's Army
events.headline: Workers march on Washington D.C. during Panic of 1893

events.originalText: New York governor Grover Cleveland signed legislation that led to the creation of Niagara Falls State Park, the United States' first state park.
events.subtitle: Grover Cleveland
events.headline: Niagara Falls State Park created by New York governor

events.originalText: George Washington took the oath of office as the first president of the United States at Federal Hall in New York City.
events.subtitle: George Washington
events.headline: George Washington sworn in as first US president at Federal Hall

events.originalText: SN 1006 (remnant pictured), the brightest supernova in recorded history, first appeared in the constellation Lupus.
events.subtitle: SN 1006
events.headline: Brightest supernova SN 1006 appears in constellation Lupus

events.originalText: The Diocletianic Persecution of Christians officially ended in the eastern Roman Empire.
events.subtitle: AD 311
events.headline: Diocletianic Persecution of Christians ends in eastern Roman Empire
